abstracts.cdata!:
The Power Rehabilitation and Extension
            Project's outcome is rated as marginally satisfactory.
            The project's institutional development objective has
            not been achieved. The performance of the Societe Beninoise
            d'Electricite et d'Eau has not been improved. The
            lessons drawn from this project include: 1) A performance
            contract may be an adequate instrument for promoting
            management autonomy. Experience has shown time that
            governments have great difficulty refraining from
            interfering in the management of their utilities. Political
            changes may bring about increased interference, as a new
            government is often keen on replacing mangers of public
            enterprises. 2) A well functioning billing system is the
            backbone of an electricity distribution company. 3)
            Coordination and consultation with donors is vital to the
            success of a jointly financed project and for the
            achievement of project's objectives. 4) Regional
            cooperation, including pooling arrangements, and common
            norms and standards, can help reduce cost to utilities and
            improve system reliability.
